conclusion: Analyze parameters affecting rate of collisions based on pressure and temperature.
Processes A→B and C→D are isothermal; temperature remains constant.
State C has higher volume and lower pressure compared to state D.
Temperature at state C is the same as at state D due to isothermal process.
Collision rate is proportional to pressure; pressure is force from molecule collisions.
Rate of collisions \( Z \) is proportional to pressure \( P \).
Ideal gas law implies pressure increases if volume decreases at constant temperature.
From C to D, volume decreases and pressure increases.
Number of molecules colliding with wall increases from state C to state D.
Final answer: Collision rate increases from state C to state D.
